August 28, 1940

cover & clippings
Dr. A. D. Albertini
Director of Finlay Institute
Havana, Cuba
My dear Doctor Albertini:
div1.p:
You may remember my visit to Havana in April when I was doing some
historical researches on the work of Dr. Finlay and the U.S. Army Yellow Fever Commission.
You will remember that for certain reasons I felt sure that the government had chosen the
wrong site of Camp Lazear and that Mr. Moran and I located the true site on the San Jose
farm, still owned by the widow of Dr. Rojas, Dr. Agramonte's friend. You will also remember
that His Excellency, Dr. Ramos, asked me to submit to him my evidence in documentary fashion
so that they would know where these sites truly were. I have sent to Mr. Moran a prelim-
inary memorandum for his correction and there is some additional information which I am
anxious to obtain. I would appreciate it greatly if you could give me some help.

Has there ever been written a pamphlet or booklet on the history of
Las Animas Hospital? and how may I obtain a copy of it?

Have the buildings been materially changed in the last forty years?
With your kind permission and the help of Dr. Castro, I obtained a photograph of the room
in which Miss Maass died and in which, according to the official record, Dr. Lazear was
bitten, but I was unable to obtain a photograph of the general group of buildings. Has
an aeroplane photograph or an aeroplane drawing of the general grounds and buildings ever
been made and could I obtain a copy? I am anxious to identify the Las Animas Hospital
with the conquest of yellow fever, and wish such a photograph or drawing not only for a
slide, to be used in my address on the occasion of the forthcoming dedication of the Lazear
Memorial Building at Washington and Jefferson College, but also to be used in publications.

Do you know when the tent Camp Columbia was erected and what was on this
site before hand, when it was replaced by the wooden buildings of Columbia Barracks, when
these were torn down and when the present Military City was erected? I have been unable to
obtain these dates. Do you know of any written history of Columbia Barracks or the Military
City?

Can you give me your own opinion as to the true location of Camp
Lazear--the experimental camp where the Infected Mosquito Building and Infected Clothing
Building were erected. Did you ever personally visit this camp? It was on the San Jose
farm and when any volunteer came down with yellow fever, he was immediately moved from this
Camp Lazear to a special yellow fever tent hospital near the grounds of the post hospital
at Columbia Barracks. It was in this yellow fever tent hospital that you visited Moran
and others with experimental yellow fever. Whatever recollections you have on this, I would
be most grateful to have. Do you have any old diary or notes of this, of your own?

May I call your attention to the fact that on the sign behind
the Military City, near the Military Hospital, that is the sign memorializing the
supposed site of Camp Lazear, they have Dr. Lazear's name spelled wrong. It is
spelled “Jess” but should have been spelled “Jesse W. Lazear”. May I also call your
attention to the fact that the sign in the Salle Guiteras at the Las Animas Hospital
in the room where Lazear was presumably bitten, his name is again misspelled. There
his name is given as Dr. James Lazear. On this sign there are two additional errors.
It says that he died in the experimental encampment at Marianao. The official record
says that he died at the post hospital, Columbia Barracks. You remember that the
experimental camp at Marianao was not set up until after his death, and it was because
of his death that it was named after him. On this sign, the date of his death is
also given erroneously. Dr. Castro copied this sign for me and according to my
notes, the sign says he died September 28. As a matter of fact, he died September 25.

May I in particular, ask you why this sign says “in this room
was bitten experimentally by a mosquito,-----etc.” My investigations have revealed
that Lazear apparently truly did inoculate himself experimentally and that he was not
accidentally bitten as the official record has it. The wording of this sign would make
me believe that you may have information on this point and I am most anxious to know
whether this is so. Dr. Castro told me that the temporary cardboard sign was to be
replaced by bronze tablets. I should appreciate knowing when this will be done, and
I sincerely hope that the corrections that I have noted above can be made before this
is done.

In the U.S. Army Medical Museum in Washington, I found a photograph
of an old model of Columbia Barracks, made by a Cuban in 1900. This model indicates
that the Columbia Barracks grounds extended back to the railroad track and for a little
ways across the railroad track, with a small bridge thrown across the railroad track.
Is this according to your recollection of the grounds at that time?

Do you have any idea where I could obtain copies of old maps or
photographs of Columbia Barracks or, particularly, the post-hospital there?

It was indeed a great pleasure for me to meet you and your
colleagues, and I sincerely hope that I may have this privilege again. Should you
ever plan to visit the Mayo Clinic, I shall be delighted to be your host and guide.
I cannot tell you how much I appreciate your great help in this matter and I can
assure you that my only interest and purpose in collecting these data is to enhance
the glory of all those who played such a glorious part in the conquest of yellow
fever. I can assure you that I shall do what I can to correct any erroneous impressions
as to the part Dr. Finlay played, and because I am desirous of giving Dr. Finlay
greater credit than has been given to him in the United States, I have written to
Dr. Dominguez and to Dr. Carlos E. Finlay, asking for whatever help they can give me,
in particular for English translations of their manuscripts on the work of Dr. Finlay.
Rest assured that before my own papers are published, I shall submit them to you and
others concerned so that the true story can be told.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
